title: How An Integrated Co-Sourcing Model Strengthens Accounting Function
description: Co-sourcing creates a structure that supports the team and adapts as the business evolves.
content:
Most accounting teams weren’t built to scale. They were built to close the books and stay compliant. That worked—until the demands outgrew the structure. Today, businesses expect sharper insight and tighter alignment between accounting, tax and planning. And leaders are trying to meet those expectations while navigating a shrinking talent pool, rising compliance demands and a wave of new technology. In particular, AI is pressuring companies to rethink headcount and get more revenue per employee to remain competitive.

These pressures are forcing companies to take a hard look at how their accounting function is built. One model that’s gaining traction and that my company champions is integrated co-sourcing—a hybrid approach that blends in-house teams with external support to create a more resilient and cost-effective structure. It’s not outsourcing, and it’s not just temporary staffing. It’s a strategic way to shore up capacity and give internal teams the breathing room to focus on what matters most. Here’s how it works and how leaders can use it to build a stronger function from the inside out.

Why The Traditional Models Are Under Strain

The accounting industry is facing a talent pipeline problem. According to Bloomberg, the pool of accountants and auditors dropped by 340,000 (registration required) in recent years. Meanwhile, fewer students are entering accounting programs. For companies trying to hire, that adds up to longer searches, higher costs and a revolving door of talent that’s tough to stabilize.

The job itself is shifting, too. Today’s accounting leaders are expected to do more than report the numbers; they’re being pulled into strategic planning, forecasting and decision support. That’s hard to deliver when teams are already stretched, and even harder when you’re constantly onboarding or scrambling to cover turnover.

Technology adds another layer. AI is high on the CFO agenda. PwC’s 2025 Pulse Survey found that 58% are investing in AI and analytics to adjust planning and improve decision making and forecasting. But without connected systems or enough internal bandwidth, those initiatives can easily lose steam before they gain traction.

To keep up, many companies try to muscle through—adding headcount, layering on new tools or asking already busy teams to do more. But an internal team can only stretch so far, especially when something unexpected comes up, such as an audit. Even the best-run departments can struggle to scale. Hiring takes time. Training takes longer. And losing a key person at the wrong moment can throw the whole operation out of sync.

Outsourcing can offer speed and flexibility, but external teams don’t always have the context to deliver the level of accuracy or insight that leaders need. And without a firm grasp of the business, continuity tends to suffer.

Rather than outsourcing the whole function, co-sourcing reinforces the team that’s already in place. You keep your internal staff where they’re strongest, then bring in outside help to fill in gaps or bring in specialized skills you don’t have in-house. Co-sourcing creates a structure that supports the team and adapts as the business evolves.

When it’s done right, co-sourcing gives companies room to grow without expanding headcount. It also shortens the ramp-up time for new capabilities, making it easier to manage changing priorities or respond quickly to things such as audits or system rollouts.

How To Make It Work

There’s no standard blueprint for co-sourcing—it must be built around the needs of the business. But one thing is consistent: It works best when it’s built around a true partnership. Leaders thinking about this approach should ask the following questions early to set it up for long-term success:
• “Where do we need the most support?” Start by taking an honest look at where your team is strong—and where it’s stretched too thin. Some departments struggle to keep the monthly close on track. Others are buried in tax complexity or stuck trying to get reports out of fragmented systems. Co-sourcing is most effective when it’s aimed at solving specific pain points, not just plugging generic staffing gaps.
• “How will we collaborate day-to-day?” Seamless collaboration takes shared systems, clear handoffs and agreed-upon workflows. Everyone must work from the same data, with a common understanding of who’s doing what, when it’s due and what the final output should look like.
• “Can the model scale with us?” A strong co-sourcing model should scale with you, whether you’re rolling out a new system or building out new reporting. It’s that ability to expand and contract without disruption that turns co-sourcing from a short-term patch into a lasting solution.

When To Go A Different Way

While the co-sourcing model offers tremendous value in the right situations, it’s not a universal solution. For companies with a well-staffed, high-performing internal finance team and mature systems in place, layering in a co-sourced model may create unnecessary complexity. In those cases, targeted project-based support or strategic advisory may be a better fit than an ongoing co-sourcing arrangement.

Co-sourcing also isn’t ideal when a client expects a full-time, on-premise resource. The co-sourcing model is designed to be flexible, efficient and tech-enabled—leveraging remote workflows and shared platforms. That said, we’ve had situations where limited in-person presence early on helped build trust and uncover additional needs. When used intentionally, being on-site can serve as a relationship accelerant, but it’s not the default approach we recommend.

Lastly, we tend to avoid co-sourcing relationships where the client expects us to fully replicate the responsibilities of a full-time controller or CFO—especially if the business lacks clarity on what they actually need. Co-sourcing works best when there’s alignment around shared ownership: The co-sourcing provider brings process, structure and expertise, but the client is still engaged and accountable. When expectations are misaligned—or when the client is looking to fully “set it and forget it”—the model breaks down. In those situations, either a full outsourced accounting model or a clear internal hire may be the better answer.

A Model For The Future Of Accounting

The accounting function is more complex than ever. Leaders are expected to deliver strategic insight, keep up with compliance, push digital initiatives forward and manage risk, all while contending with a shrinking talent pool.

Co-sourcing offers a practical way through. By combining internal strengths with outside support, you gain the flexibility, expertise and resilience needed to support your business today and prepare it for what’s next.
